Subjective: Fatigue for ~2 months; wakes up tired despite sleeping a lot. Sleep sometimes superficial. Increased muscle pain and back pain. Morning stiffness noted. Work is manageable but difficult; rests on weekends. Continues climbing 2-3x/week and cycling without significant decline in performance or muscle power. No shortness of breath, acid reflux, chest pain, palpitations, snoring, specific joint pain (hands/feet), appetite change, or weight change. Stable weight at 72 kg. Normal bowel movements (3-4x/day) and urination. Hay fever controlled with medication. Father with history of back problems. Concern: 'Is there something wrong with my body?'. Idea: Possible rheumatism from online search. Request: Blood tests to investigate cause.
Objective: Vitals: BP 110/60, HR 40-60 bpm. Lungs: Clear to auscultation. Heart: Normal sounds. Back: Mild tenderness on palpation paravertebrally in lower back. No vertebral tenderness. No pain on pelvic compression. Neck/Shoulders: Full range of motion, no pain. Abdomen: Supple, non-tender, lively peristalsis, normal to percussion.
Assessment: Fatigue, unspecified. Myalgia and back pain. Differential diagnosis includes anemia, thyroid dysfunction, and inflammatory conditions. Rheumatoid arthritis considered unlikely. No signs of cardiopulmonary disease.
Plan: 1. Lab work: Order blood tests for anemia (CBC), thyroid function (TSH), and inflammation markers. 2. Patient to schedule blood draw at lab. 3. Follow-up: Patient to call clinic one day after blood draw to schedule a phone appointment for results.
